articles.headline: Inside the Prisoner Swap That Freed Brittney Griner
articles.snippet: U.S. officials say Moscow had been pushing for the release of a Russian assassin being held in Germany before finally agreeing to release Ms. Griner for Viktor Bout, a Russian arms dealer.
articles.abstract: U.S. officials say Moscow had been pushing for the release of a Russian assassin being held in Germany before finally agreeing to release Ms. Griner for Viktor Bout, a Russian arms dealer.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Month after month, as American diplomats pushed for the release of Brittney Griner and Paul Whelan from Russian prisons, they received the same, infuriating answer: If you want both prisoners, we want Vadim Krasikov as part of the deal.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Peter Baker

articles.headline: Recruited for Navy SEALs, Many Sailors Wind Up Scraping Paint
articles.snippet: The high failure rate of the elite force’s selection course shunts hundreds of candidates into low-skilled jobs.
articles.abstract: The high failure rate of the elite force’s selection course shunts hundreds of candidates into low-skilled jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAVAL BASE KITSAP, Wash. — A sailor fresh out of the elite Navy SEAL selection course slung his gear over his broad shoulder and clomped down a steel ladder into the guts of a Navy ship to execute a difficult, dayslong mission specifically assigned to him: scrubbing the stinking scum out of the ship’s cavernous bilge tank.

articles.headline: Can Humans Find Common Ground? Sure. Just Start With Sea Slugs.
articles.snippet: As civil discourse online and off increasingly proves elusive, a website devoted to identifying plants and animals may be teaching humans how to get along.
articles.abstract: As civil discourse online and off increasingly proves elusive, a website devoted to identifying plants and animals may be teaching humans how to get along.

articles.headline: Lina Khan, Aiming to Block Microsoft’s Activision Deal, Faces a Challenge
articles.snippet: Ms. Khan, the chair of the Federal Trade Commission, has staked an ambitious trustbusting agenda on a case that may be difficult to win.
articles.abstract: Ms. Khan, the chair of the Federal Trade Commission, has staked an ambitious trustbusting agenda on a case that may be difficult to win.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lina Khan, the chair of the Federal Trade Commission, has pledged to usher in a new era of trustbusting of America’s corporate giants, recently saying the agency plans to “enforce the antitrust laws to ensure maximal efficacy.”
articles.byline: By David McCabe, Cecilia Kang and Karen Weise

articles.headline: Sinema Adds Intrigue and Democratic Fury to Arizona’s 2024 Senate Race
articles.snippet: Senator Kyrsten Sinema’s announcement that she would become an independent left Democrats in her state, many of whom have long wanted to defeat her in a primary, facing a new political calculus.
articles.abstract: Senator Kyrsten Sinema’s announcement that she would become an independent left Democrats in her state, many of whom have long wanted to defeat her in a primary, facing a new political calculus.
articles.lead_paragraph: The one constant in Senator Kyrsten Sinema’s political career, from her start as a left-wing rabble rouser and Ralph Nader aide to her announcement on Friday that she was leaving the Democratic Party to become an independent, is her boundless ability to draw attention to herself.
articles.byline: By Reid J. Epstein, Jennifer Medina and Katie Glueck

articles.headline: Critics Say Musk Has Revealed Himself as a Conservative. It’s Not So Simple.
articles.snippet: Elon Musk has tweeted about political topics regularly since taking over Twitter, often belittling some liberal causes. But what he stands for remains largely unclear.
articles.abstract: Elon Musk has tweeted about political topics regularly since taking over Twitter, often belittling some liberal causes. But what he stands for remains largely unclear.
articles.lead_paragraph: He has called himself an independent and a centrist, yet “economically right of center, maybe.” He has said he was until recently a supporter of only Democrats and voted for President Biden. He’s encouraged people to vote Republican, which he said he did for the first time this year. Last year, he once even declared himself indifferent about politics, saying he’d rather stay out of it altogether.

articles.headline: The New Landscape of the Abortion Fight
articles.snippet: After the midterm elections, abortion rights advocates hope to harness public support for the long term, while abortion foes look to advance new laws in sympathetic courts and legislatures.
articles.abstract: After the midterm elections, abortion rights advocates hope to harness public support for the long term, while abortion foes look to advance new laws in sympathetic courts and legislatures.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court’s reversal of the 50-year-old decision in Roe v. Wade transformed the debate and politics around abortion in the United States, shifting battles to state courts and legislatures — and galvanizing a fresh wave of voters in the midterm elections who turned out more forcefully than ever to make abortion rights a winning issue.

articles.headline: ‘Cuba Is Depopulating’: Largest Exodus Yet Threatens Country’s Future
articles.snippet: The pandemic and tougher U.S. sanctions have decimated Cuba’s economy, prompting the biggest migration since Fidel Castro rose to power.
articles.abstract: The pandemic and tougher U.S. sanctions have decimated Cuba’s economy, prompting the biggest migration since Fidel Castro rose to power.
articles.lead_paragraph: BARACOA, Cuba — Roger García Ordaz makes no secret of his many attempts to flee.
articles.byline: By Ed Augustin and Frances Robles

articles.headline: Even as China Eases Covid Rules, Some Youths Still Fear a Grim Future
articles.snippet: A sluggish economy continues to leave many young people unemployed, with few job prospects or hopes to tap into the rising incomes their parents enjoyed during boom times.
articles.abstract: A sluggish economy continues to leave many young people unemployed, with few job prospects or hopes to tap into the rising incomes their parents enjoyed during boom times.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mandy Liu, a 21-year-old university student in Beijing, believes that anyone who has lived in China during the pandemic can see that the country’s future is looking increasingly uncertain.
articles.byline: By Daisuke Wakabayashi, Claire Fu, Isabelle Qian and Amy Chang Chien

articles.headline: The New Chatbots Could Change the World. Can You Trust Them?
articles.snippet: Siri, Google Search, online marketing and your child’s homework will never be the same. Then there’s the misinformation problem.
articles.abstract: Siri, Google Search, online marketing and your child’s homework will never be the same. Then there’s the misinformation problem.
articles.lead_paragraph: This month, Jeremy Howard, an artificial intelligence researcher, introduced an online chatbot called ChatGPT to his 7-year-old daughter. It had been released a few days earlier by OpenAI, one of the world’s most ambitious A.I. labs.

articles.headline: Wish You Were Here. Ignore the Floods and Fires.
articles.snippet: Climate change is reshaping the American economy. New Mexico is leaning on ecotourism and sustainable industries to see it through, but extreme weather keeps getting in the way.
articles.abstract: Climate change is reshaping the American economy. New Mexico is leaning on ecotourism and sustainable industries to see it through, but extreme weather keeps getting in the way.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rock Ulibarri had a vision for his ancestral homestead nestled in a canyon in the mountains of northeast New Mexico: Open it up to tourists, who would pay for pit-smoked pork, mountain bike tours of the craggy terrain and work from local artisans.

articles.headline: War Next Door Brings Energy Crunch, and Paid Protests, to Moldova
articles.snippet: The tiny country, starved of natural gas and electricity because of the conflict in neighboring Ukraine, is confronting street rallies bankrolled by a pro-Russian politician to target its pro-Western government.
articles.abstract: The tiny country, starved of natural gas and electricity because of the conflict in neighboring Ukraine, is confronting street rallies bankrolled by a pro-Russian politician to target its pro-Western government.
articles.lead_paragraph: ORHEI, Moldova — Starved of natural gas from Russia and electricity from Ukraine’s missile-battered power grid, Moldova has been so unsettled by skyrocketing utility bills and occasional blackouts that, according to the mayor of a small city in the north, residents can barely contain their anger.

articles.headline: Thousands of Teens Are Being Pushed Into Military’s Junior R.O.T.C.
articles.snippet: In high schools across the country, students are being placed in military classes without electing them on their own. “The only word I can think of is ‘indoctrination,’” one parent said.
articles.abstract: In high schools across the country, students are being placed in military classes without electing them on their own. “The only word I can think of is ‘indoctrination,’” one parent said.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
articles.byline: By Mike Baker, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Ilana Marcus

articles.headline: The Prince, the Plot and a Long-Lost Reich
articles.snippet: Prince Heinrich XIII was arrested last week as the suspected ringleader of a plan to overthrow the German government. Nostalgic for an imperial past, he embraced far-right conspiracy theories.
articles.abstract: Prince Heinrich XIII was arrested last week as the suspected ringleader of a plan to overthrow the German government. Nostalgic for an imperial past, he embraced far-right conspiracy theories.
articles.lead_paragraph: The crenelated hunting lodge of Prince Heinrich XIII of Reuss sits atop a steep hill, looking out over homes laced with snow and Christmas lights in Bad Lobenstein. Popular with the local mayor and many nearby villagers, the prince spent his weekends in the spa town, giving an aristocratic flair to this sleepy corner of rural eastern Germany.
articles.byline: By Erika Solomon and Katrin Bennhold

articles.headline: In Hostage Diplomacy, It’s Often the Hostage-Takers Who Pay
articles.snippet: Detaining foreigners to wring concessions from their home country’s government holds perils for both sides, but especially, perhaps surprisingly, for the hostage takers.
articles.abstract: Detaining foreigners to wring concessions from their home country’s government holds perils for both sides, but especially, perhaps surprisingly, for the hostage takers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Brittney Griner’s release, nearly a year after Russian authorities detained her, is once more forcing a difficult question in Washington and other capitals. What is the least bad option in dealing with hostage diplomacy?

articles.headline: Some Prisoners Remain Behind Bars in Louisiana Despite Being Deemed Free
articles.snippet: About 200 to 250 inmates are held beyond their legal release dates in any given month, with the average additional time lasting around 44 days in 2019.
articles.abstract: About 200 to 250 inmates are held beyond their legal release dates in any given month, with the average additional time lasting around 44 days in 2019.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — The judge told Johnny Traweek he had served his time, seven months, for hitting someone with a saucepan in a drunken fight, then suggested he could be released from the Orleans Parish prison by midnight.

articles.headline: Japan Needs Indian Tech Workers. But Do They Need Japan?
articles.snippet: Recruiters call the push a crucial test of whether the world’s third-largest economy can compete with the U.S. and Europe for global talent.
articles.abstract: Recruiters call the push a crucial test of whether the world’s third-largest economy can compete with the U.S. and Europe for global talent.
articles.lead_paragraph: In many ways, Yogendra Puranik is an immigrant success story.

articles.headline: Inflation Forecasts Were Wrong Last Year. Should We Believe Them Now?
articles.snippet: Economists misjudged how much staying power inflation would have. Next year could be better — but there’s ample room for humility.
articles.abstract: Economists misjudged how much staying power inflation would have. Next year could be better — but there’s ample room for humility.
articles.lead_paragraph: At this time last year, economists were predicting that inflation would swiftly fade in 2022 as supply chain issues cleared, consumers shifted from goods to services spending and pandemic relief waned. They are now forecasting the same thing for 2023, citing many of the same reasons.

articles.headline: Wall Street Journal Names a New Editor
articles.snippet: News Corp said that Emma Tucker, a longtime editor in London, would replace Matt Murray, who has led the news organization for four years.
articles.abstract: News Corp said that Emma Tucker, a longtime editor in London, would replace Matt Murray, who has led the news organization for four years.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Wall Street Journal named a new top editor on Monday, saying it would hand control of the newsroom to Emma Tucker, a longtime editor for Rupert Murdoch-owned newspapers in Britain. She replaces Matt Murray, who has led the paper for the past four years, occasionally clashing with the paper’s publisher.
articles.byline: By Katie Robertson, Edmund Lee and Benjamin Mullin
